EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ocean storm system moved north, passing east of New England on Tuesday, October 25th and Wednesday, October 26th. Rain on the 25th of October changed to snow by early afternoon in the higher terrain. This heavy wet snow was accompanied by gusty winds. With foliage still on the trees, the weight of the snow easily took many trees and tree limbs down with extensive power outages. During the evening, it was clearly evident that the impact of the storm was being felt with 3 to 6 inches of heavy wet snow. Total snow accumulations in this area were 5 to 10 inches with lesser amounts in some sheltered valleys. Specifically, Ellenburg Depot (western Clinton county) received 10 inches, while the Franklin county towns of Whippleville received 9 inches, and Tupper Lake 5 inches. In western Essex county, Lake Placid received 6 1/2 inches of heavy wet snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that multiple trees and power lines were brought down across roadways in Cedarville, Winfield, Frankfort Hill and Fairfield in southern Herkimer County from heavy wet snow.  Snow depth on the ground was estimated to be 5 inches in the town of Fairfield.  Power outages were reported north of Little Falls between 6 PM and 8 PM EST on October 25.

Law enforcement personnel reported that trees and wires were down on Corbin Hill Road in the town of Charleston due to heavy wet snow.  However, the snow depth on the ground was estimated to be only 3 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the period October 25 through 26, an extratropical cyclone drew in warm moist tropical air from the remnant of hurricane Wilma to become a powerful storm centered off the southern New England coast.  The storm brought heavy rain and snow to eastern New York.  Heavy snow was confined mostly to elevations above about 15 hundred feet in the southern Adirondack and Catskill mountains.  Minor flooding occurred as some small streams and main stem rivers overflowed their banks.  The flooding occurred southward from the Mohawk River where 1.5 to 3 inches of rainfall accumulated during the storm.

Low pressure brought a mix of wintry precipitation to parts of the Finger Lakes region during the overnight. Freezing rain accumulated up to a quarter inch of ice before the precipitation changed to snow. Five to seven inches of snow then fell on top of the ice, before tapering off during the morning hours.

Surface low pressure moving up the east coast brought copious moisture north ahead of it.  Snow started across the area starting the afternoon of the 15th.  During the evening the snow changed to sleet and freezing rain.  Toward morning some of the valleys had warmed up above freezing so the precipitation was rain.  The freezing rain and rain ended everywhere by 9 am.  Freezing rain amounts were up to half an inch with the highest amounts across the hilltops.  Liquid amounts were around 1 inch.  The mixed precipitation on the roads created many vehicular accidents.

A storm system developed over the lower Mississippi Valley early on the 15th of December and moved northeast to western Long Island of New York early on the 16th of December. The storm continued northeast into the Gulf of Maine by the evening of December 16th. Snow, sleet and freezing rain overspread the area during the late night of December 15th and early morning of December 16th. During the morning of the 16th, steady snow and sleet fell as warm air moved in aloft. Accumulations of snow and sleet across much of western Clinton county was 9 to 12 inches. In Dannemora, NY (western Clinton county) 12 inches fell.

A storm system developed over the lower Mississippi Valley early on the 15th of December and moved northeast to western Long Island of New York early on the 16th of December. The storm continued northeast into the Gulf of Maine by the evening of December 16th. Snow, sleet and freezing rain overspread the area during the late night of December 15th and early morning of December 16th. During the morning of the 16th, steady snow and sleet fell as warm air moved in aloft. Accumulations of snow and sleet across this portion of  northern New York was between 6 and 10 inches. In Peru, NY (eastern Clinton county) 9.4 inches fell, while in Malone, NY (northern Franklin county) 9 inches fell.

A low pressure system tracked into the Ohio Valley Monday night on the 2nd and weakened, while a secondary low formed off the Mid-Atlantic Coast Tuesday the 3rd while tracking out to sea. The storm system brought a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to upstate New York and northeast Pennsylvania Monday night and Tuesday morning. The snow and mixed precipitation tapered off by  Tuesday afternoon. While snow accumulations were generally less than 6 inches across the area, some locations received higher amounts. In Sullivan County, snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to 14 inches with Bloomingburg measuring 13.5 inches, while Liberty had 11.5 inches. In Otsego County, Laurens received 8.0 inches with the rest of the county seeing less than 4 inches. Pleasant Mount in Wayne County, Pennsylvania measured 7.0 inches of new snow.

An unusually strong Alberta clipper moved southeast across the southern Adirondacks between late morning and early afternoon of the 25th. Snow started across St. Lawrence county by mid-morning, reaching the southern Champlain Valley by late morning and quickly became steadier and heavier through the afternoon, before dissipating that evening. Snowfall was generally 6 to 10 inches. Some specific snowfall totals include: 6 inches in Gouverneur (St. Lawrence), 7 inches in Ticonderoga (Essex), 8 inches in Bloomingdale (Essex)...9 inches in Edwards (St. Lawrence), Tupper Lake (Franklin) and Moriah (Essex) with 10 inches in Newcomb (Essex).

A low pressure system emerged from the Ohio Valley Thursday morning, March 2, and tracked off the northern Middle Atlantic Coast during the afternoon and evening hours.  This storm moved south and east of New York City.  Snow broke out across the east end of Long Island around 10 am and tapered off between 7 and 9 pm.   Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches.  During the early afternoon hours, the snow mixed with or briefly changed to freezing rain.  This event had a high impact as the heaviest snow fell during the evening commute.  Many traffic accidents were reported across the region.

Here are selected snowfall amounts for Suffolk County:  Cutchogue 4.7 inches, Sag Harbor 3.9 inches.

A low pressure system emerged from the Ohio Valley Thursday morning, March 2, and tracked off the northern Middle Atlantic Coast during the afternoon and evening hours.  This storm moved south and east of New York City.  Snow broke out across the Lower Hudson Valley around 8 am and tapered off between 5 and 6 pm.   Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches.  During the early afternoon hours the snow mixed with sleet and freezing drizzle. This event had a high impact as it affected both the morning and early evening commutes.  Many traffic accidents were reported across the region.

Here are selected snowfall amounts for:

Orange County - Newburgh 7.0 inches; Hamptonburgh, New Windsor, and Westtown 5.0 inches
Rockland County - Stony Point 4.4 inches
Westchester County- Yorktown Heights 4.5 inches.

Low pressure centered over southern Indiana tracked northeast and spread freezing rain across the area. Up to a half-inch of ice accumulated on trees and wires. The weight brought down some power lines with outages scattered throughout the area.  Heavy icing was reported in Fulton, Warsaw, Livonia, Geneva, Henderson and North Osceola.

A powerful and large storm in New Brunswick and the Canadian Maritimes on the 19th and 20th, delivered a cold and unstable air flow into the Adirondacks. This unstable northwest flow accounted for upslope snow conditions to develop on the northwest facing slopes of Clinton and Franklin counties during the evening of the 19th and continued through the morning hours of the 20th. Snowfall amounts of 6 to 12 inches occurred, including 6 inches at Dannermora and Ellenburg Depot (Clinton), 11 inches at Vermontville (Franklin) and 12 inches at Duane (Franklin).

A powerful and large storm in New Brunswick and the Canadian Maritimes on the 19th and 20th, delivered a cold and unstable air flow into the Adirondacks. This unstable northwest flow accounted for upslope snow conditions to develop on the northwest facing slopes of Clinton and Franklin counties during the evening of the 19th and continued through the morning hours of the 20th. Snowfall amounts of 6 to 12 inches occurred, including 6 inches at Dannermora and Ellenburg Depot (Clinton), 11 inches at Vermontville (Franklin) and 12 inches at Duane (Franklin).

A low pressure system developed over the southern plains on February 12th, and intensified rapidly as it neared the East Coast on the night of the 13th. The storm then continued to strengthen as it moved up the Atlantic Seaboard during the day on February 14th. The storm spread snow into central New York beginning the evening of Tuesday, the 13th. The snow continued heavy at times through the 14th and gradually tapered off to snow showers on the 15th as the storm pulled northeast past the Gulf of Maine. Some sleet mixed with the snow for brief periods of time. The snow became heavy with near blizzard conditions at times over the Finger Lakes and central southern tier of New York during the early morning hours of the 14th. The heavy snow and near blizzard conditions shifted east to the upper Susquehanna Region of New York and western Mohawk Valley by the afternoon and evening of the 14th. Gusty winds to 40 mph developed behind the storm late on the 14th and through the 15th which led to considerable blowing and drifting snow. This hampered snow plowing and snow cleanup operations. As a result, many roads and highways were closed during the height of the snowstorm. Many counties and municipalities declared snow emergencies. Storm total snowfall amounts across much of central New York ranged between 15 and 30 inches. Less snow fell in Sullivan County, New York where more sleet was reported. This kept snowfall amounts down between 8 and 12 inches in this area. The heaviest snowfall from this storm occurred in Delaware and Otsego counties where between 2 and 3 feet was common. The highest snowfall was reported in Roseboom where 39 inches of snow occurred and Springfield where 38 inches fell. The weight of the snow caused several roofs to collapse.

A low pressure system developed over the southern plains on February 12th, and intensified rapidly as it neared the East Coast on the night of the 13th. The storm then continued to strengthen as it moved up the Atlantic Seaboard during the day on February 14th. The storm spread snow into central New York beginning the evening of Tuesday, the 13th. The snow continued heavy at times through the 14th and gradually tapered off to snow showers on the 15th as the storm pulled northeast past the Gulf of Maine. Some sleet mixed with the snow for brief periods of time. The snow became heavy with near blizzard conditions at times over the Finger Lakes and central southern tier of New York during the early morning hours of the 14th. The heavy snow and near blizzard conditions shifted east to the upper Susquehanna Region of New York and western Mohawk Valley by the afternoon and evening of the 14th. Gusty winds to 40 mph developed behind the storm late on the 14th and through the 15th which led to considerable blowing and drifting snow. This hampered snow plowing and snow cleanup operations. As a result, many roads and highways were closed during the height of the snowstorm. Many counties and municipalities declared snow emergencies. Storm total snowfall amounts across much of central New York ranged between 15 and 30 inches. Less snow fell in Sullivan County, New York where more sleet was reported. This kept snowfall amounts down between 8 and 12 inches in this area. The heaviest snowfall from this storm occurred in Delaware and Otsego counties where between 2 and 3 feet was common. The highest snowfall was reported in Roseboom where 39 inches of snow occurred and Springfield where 38 inches fell. The weight of the snow caused several roofs to collapse.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow began during the late evening on Tuesday Feb. 13, then mixed with sleet during the early morning hours. A moderate to heavy sleet developed Wednesday morning, Feb. 14, and continued into the early afternoon before ending as some light snow. The accumulation of 2 to 4 inches of sleet caused major mass transit problems along with severe delays at the major airports.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a ridge of high pressure extending from north of the Great Lakes southeast across southern New England moved slowly northeast, a low pressure system developed off the Carolina coast.  As this low moved north to northeast just off the mid Atlantic coast, it rapidly intensified during Wednesday morning.  This low moved across eastern Long Island during the early afternoon hours. |These systems produced snow, sleet, freezing rain, rain, strong gusty winds, and minor tidal flooding across the region. |Light snow developed from southwest to northeast during Tuesday evening between 5 p.m. and 10 p.m.  It mixed with sleet and freezing rain, first across eastern Long Island between midnight and 3 a.m. and then across the remainder of the area between 3 a.m. and 6 a.m.  By 6 a.m., a mixed bag of sleet and freezing rain occurred everywhere with temperatures ranging from the lower 30s across eastern Long Island, to 10 degrees in the Lower Hudson Valley, to 19 degrees at Central Park. |As the deepening low moved more to the northeast, cold air was locked in west of the storm track, prompting the issuance of Ice Storm Warnings for Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau, and NW Suffolk between 10 a.m. and 10:15 a.m.  Six hour precipitation totals between 7 a.m. and 1 p.m. were between 0.50 and 0.75 inches.  This fell as mainly plain rain across the twin forks, and much of Suffolk County; a combo of sleet and freezing rain fell across Nassau; and mainly sleet with some freezing rain elsewhere including NYC.

This low moved across eastern Long Island during the early afternoon hours. |These systems produced snow, sleet, freezing rain, rain, strong gusty winds, and minor tidal flooding across the region. |Light snow developed from southwest to northeast during Tuesday evening between 5 p.m. and 10 p.m.  It mixed with sleet and freezing rain, first across eastern Long Island between midnight and 3 a.m. and then across the remainder of the area between 3 a.m. and 6 a.m.  By 6 a.m., a mixed bag of sleet and freezing rain occurred everywhere with temperatures ranging from the lower 30s across eastern Long Island, to 10 degrees in the Lower Hudson Valley, to 19 degrees at Central Park. |As the deepening low moved more to the northeast, cold air was locked in west of the storm track, prompting the issuance of Ice Storm Warnings for Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau, and NW Suffolk between 10 a.m. and 10:15 a.m.  Six hour precipitation totals between 7 a.m. and 1 p.m. were between 0.50 and 0.75 inches.  This fell as mainly plain rain across the twin forks, and much of Suffolk County; a combo of sleet and freezing rain fell across Nassau; and mainly sleet with some freezing rain elsewhere including NYC.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow began during the late evening on Tuesday Feb. 13, then mixed with sleet during the early morning hours. A moderate to heavy sleet developed Wednesday morning, Feb. 14, and continued into the early afternoon before ending as some light snow. The accumulation of 2 to 4 inches of sleet caused major mass transit problems along with severe delays at the major airports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of heavy snow, sleet, and freezing rain fell across the county from late Tuesday evening, Feb. 13, through Wednesday afternoon, Feb. 14. Snow and ice totals ranged from 6 to 8 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow began during the late evening on Tuesday Feb. 13, then mixed with sleet and freezing rain during the early morning hours. A moderate to heavy mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain developed Wednesday morning, Feb. 14, and continued into the early afternoon before ending as some light snow. The accumulation of 2 to 4 inches of snow and ice caused major mass transit problems, especially during the morning and evening commutes.

A low pressure system developed over the lower Mississippi Valley on Tuesday February 13th, and then tracked northeast, reaching the mid Atlantic coast by Wednesday morning on February 14th, while intensifying. The storm continued to strengthen during the day on February 14th, before moving off the New England coast by Wednesday night.|The storm spread a swath of very heavy snowfall across eastern New York and western New England, which started during the late evening hours of Tuesday, and tapered off late Wednesday night.|Snowfall amounts ranged from 1 to 3 feet across the hardest hit areas of New York State, which included the Schoharie Valley, western Mohawk Valley, and southern Adirondacks.  Amounts as high as 40 to 42 inches occurred in portions of western Montgomery County and southern Herkimer County. Slightly lower amounts occurred across the lower mid Hudson Valley, where sleet mixed in with the snow.|This storm significantly impacted travel and commerce across the region from Wednesday through Thursday, as many schools and businesses were closed.  Many roadways became impassable by Wednesday afternoon.|In addition, in Wappingers Falls in western Dutchess County, a roof collapse occurred due to the weight of heavy sleet and snow accumulation on a structure.  Although 20 people were displaced, there were no reports of injuries.|Strong winds also created near blizzard conditions at times during Wednesday afternoon and evening.

Amounts as high as 40 to 42 inches occurred in portions of western Montgomery County and southern Herkimer County. Slightly lower amounts occurred across the lower mid Hudson Valley, where sleet mixed in with the snow.|This storm significantly impacted travel and commerce across the region from Wednesday through Thursday, as many schools and businesses were closed.  Many roadways became impassable by Wednesday afternoon.|In addition, in Wappingers Falls in western Dutchess County, a roof collapse occurred due to the weight of heavy sleet and snow accumulation on a structure.  Although 20 people were displaced, there were no reports of injuries.|Strong winds also created near blizzard conditions at times during Wednesday afternoon and evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roof collapse occurred in Wappingers Falls, due to the combined weight of heavy sleet and snow accumulation on a structure.  Although 20 people were displaced, there were no reports of injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of heavier snow brought between 4 and 11 inches of snow to the county. Roxbury measured 11.1 inches and Stamford received 9 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the Great Lakes intensified as it moved southeast across central New York and northeast Pennsylvania on the 22nd. Initially, the air was mild ahead of the storm. But a strong cold front pushed through the region in the afternoon, accompanied by snow and wind. As the storm moved off the southern New England coast, snow heavy at times, affected most of eastern New York, including Delaware county. The storm brought between 4 and 11 inches of snow to Delaware county. Roxbury measured 11.1 inches and Stamford received 9 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous tree limbs and scattered power lines were reported down due to the accretion of ice from freezing rain. Estimated ice accretions were around, or just over one half of an inch.|In addition, several inches of snow and sleet occurred from Thursday night into early Friday morning.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed over the mid Mississippi Valley on Thursday morning, March 1st, and then intensified, while reaching the western Great Lakes by Thursday evening.  A warm front attached to this low approached eastern New York and western New England from the south late Thursday night, accompanied by a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain.  Another low pressure system developed along the approaching warm front over eastern Maryland by Friday morning, March 2nd, which then strengthened and tracked northeast, reaching the northern New England coast by Friday evening.|As warm air aloft moved into the region, while cold and dry air lingered near the surface, a significant mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred. Heavy snowfall accumulations of 6 to 12 inches fell across portions of the southern Adirondacks, extending into the northern Taconics.  Meanwhile, a significant accretion of ice from freezing rain led to some downed tree limbs and power lines across portions of the upper Mohawk Valley.|This storm had an adverse impact on travel across the region during Friday, particularly during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall fell across northern portions of the county, with 10 inches reported at Blue Mountain Lake, and 8 inches at Indian Lake.|The snow began Thursday night, and tapered off by Friday evening.|In addition to the heavy snowfall, sleet and freezing rain occurred across central and southern portions of the county, with ice accretion of up to one half of an inch from freezing rain, mainly across southern portions of the county.

Another low pressure system developed along the approaching warm front over eastern Maryland by Friday morning, March 2nd, which then strengthened and tracked northeast, reaching the northern New England coast by Friday evening.|As warm air aloft moved into the region, while cold and dry air lingered near the surface, a significant mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow and sleet developed late Thursday night, and then changed to mainly freezing rain during the early morning hours of Friday. Ice accretion in excess of one half of an inch occurred, with 0.60 reported at Cedarville.|This ice accretion led to numerous downed tree limbs, and scattered downed power lines by Friday morning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall occurred across northern Warren county, which began late Thursday evening, and persisted into Friday evening.|Total snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 12 inches, with 12 inches reported at North River, 9 inches reported at Bakers Mills, and 7 inches reported at Bolton Landing, Lake George and Warrensburg.|The snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain at times during Friday afternoon.

A large storm system moved from the Mississippi River valley on the 1st into the Great Lakes on the 2nd, before dissipating north of the Great Lakes on the 3rd. Meanwhile, low pressure developed over the mid-Atlantic coast on the morning of the 2nd, along a boundary that extended from the Great Lakes storm, and moved across eastern New England by nightfall. Snow moved into northern New York around midnight on the 2nd and mixed with sleet and freezing rain before ending by late afternoon.|The combined snow and sleet accumulations across Clinton and Essex counties was 6 to 10 inches that resulted in several vehicle accidents due to the treacherous roads. Some specific accumulations include; 6 inches in AuSable Chasm (Clinton), 7 inches in Plattsburgh (Clinton)and Newcomb (Essex), 8 inches in Moriah (Essex)and Ellenburg Depot (Clinton), 9 inches in Mooers (Clinton) and Crown Point (Essex) and 10 inches in Peru (Clinton).

A cold front slipped south of the tri-state area during the day on Thursday, March 15.  This allowed colder air to work into the region after several days of anomalously warm temperatures.  Farther to the south, along the Gulf Coast, low pressure developed and deepened as it tracked northeast along the boundary.  The deepening low tracked to near the Mid Atlantic coast Friday evening, March 16, to just east of Montauk Point Saturday morning, March 17. |Initially, the precipitation started off as a light mix of snow, sleet, and rain during the early morning hours, but, as the colder air continued to deepen, the preciptation fell primarily as a mix of snow and sleet during the daytime hours, falling moderate to occasionally heavy at times. The precipitation fell primariliy as snow across the Lower Hudson Valley, while New York City and Long Island were primarily a mix of sleet and snow.  During the evening hours, inland areas began to mix more with sleet, while at the coast some areas changed over to plain rain. |Snow and sleet totals ranged from 8 to 13 inches in the Lower Hudson Valley, to 3 to 6 inches in New York City and 2 to 7 inches across Long Island.  At Central Park, 5.5 inches was measured; 4.5 inches at LaGuardia Airport; 2.7 inches at JFK Airport, and 3.3 inches at Islip Airport.|In addition, there were major impacts on mass transit with high winds and heavy wintry precipitation during the evening rush-hour traffic. Hundreds of flights were cancelled at the metropolitan airports with many planes stuck on the tarmac.

At Central Park, 5.5 inches was measured; 4.5 inches at LaGuardia Airport; 2.7 inches at JFK Airport, and 3.3 inches at Islip Airport.|In addition, there were major impacts on mass transit with high winds and heavy wintry precipitation during the evening rush-hour traffic. Hundreds of flights were cancelled at the metropolitan airports with many planes stuck on the tarmac.

A cold front slipped south of the tri-state area during the day on Thursday, March 15.  This allowed colder air to work into the region after several days of anomalously warm temperatures.  Farther to the south, along the Gulf Coast, low pressure developed and deepened as it tracked northeast along the boundary.  The deepening low tracked to near the Mid Atlantic coast Friday evening, March 16, to just east of Montauk Point Saturday morning, March 17. |Initially, the precipitation started off as a light mix of snow, sleet, and rain during the early morning hours, but, as the colder air continued to deepen, the preciptation fell primarily as a mix of snow and sleet during the daytime hours, falling moderate to occasionally heavy at times. The precipitation fell primariliy as snow across the Lower Hudson Valley, while New York City and Long Island were primarily a mix of sleet and snow.  During the evening hours, inland areas began to mix more with sleet, while at the coast some areas changed over to plain rain. |Snow and sleet totals ranged from 8 to 13 inches in the Lower Hudson Valley, to 3 to 6 inches in New York City and 2 to 7 inches across Long Island. Hundreds of flights were cancelled at the metropolitan airports with many planes stuck on the tarmac.

A low pressure system developed over the southeast states during Thursday afternoon on March 15th, and then tracked northeast while intensifying, reaching the Delmarva coast by Friday evening on March 16th, and off the New England coast by Saturday morning on March 17th.|This storm brought widespread snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 inches across eastern New York and western New England, with some amounts of near two feet across the eastern Catskill region, as well as within a band extending across southern Columbia, and northern Dutchess counties of New York.  The snow began across the lower mid Hudson Valley during the mid morning hours of Friday, March 16th, and spread into the Capital Region during midday.  The snow did not reach portions of the western Mohawk Valley and southern Adirondacks until the late afternoon hours, as dry air remained in place longer, allowing the precipitation to remain aloft for several hours before reaching the ground.  This also allowed snowfall amounts to be less across this region, with generally 6 to 9 inches occurring.|Further to the southeast, some sleet mixed in with the snow, beginning during the early evening hours of Friday, and persisting into Friday night, keeping snowfall amounts a bit less across the lower mid Hudson Valley, where an average of 8 to 12 inches occurred.|This storm had significant adverse impacts to travel and commerce across the region from Friday afternoon into early Saturday morning. Travel was treacherous for the Friday evening commute, with numerous accidents reported.

An area of low pressure developed along a stationary boundary across the Carolinas on the 16th and moved north along the East coast to Long Island by the morning of the 17th, before it moved into the Gulf of Maine by the afternoon. Snow overspread northern New York during the late afternoon/early evening of the 16th and became heavy at times during the early  morning of the 17th, before it tapered off to scattered snow showers by mid-morning. Snowfall totals ranged from 6-8 inches in Franklin and western portions of Clinton and Essex counties to around a foot in the Champlain Valley of New York.|Some specific snowfall totals include; 6 inches in Saranac Lake (Franklin), 8 inches in Tupper Lake (Franklin) and Ellenburg Depot (Clinton), 10 inches in Jay (Essex)and Schuyler Falls (Clinton), 11 inches in Mooers (Clinton) and Peru (Essex), 12 inches in Plattsburgh and Dannemora (Clinton), Crown Point and Wilmington (Essex).

Low pressure moved from the mid Mississippi Valley on Wednesday April 11th into the southern Great Lakes by Thursday morning on April 12th, spreading a swath of heavy wet snow across the higher elevations of the southern Adirondacks and eastern Mohawk Valley from early Thursday morning into early Thursday afternoon.| |Snowfall amounts were greatest across the higher elevations above 1500 feet, where 6 to 12 inches fell.  Some snowfall totals included 10.5 inches at Speculator, 10.3 inches at Wells, 8 inches at Caroga Lake and Stratford, 8 inches at Middle Grove, 12 inches at North Creek at an elevation of 3600 feet, and 10 inches at Bakers Mills.|The heavy wet snowfall led to downed tree limbs and power lines, which led to numerous power outages across the affected region during Thursday afternoon.|The snow tapered off by early Thursday afternoon.

Strong low pressure moved into the Great Lakes on the morning of the 12th. Meanwhile, a secondary area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva pennisula during the afternoon of the 12th. Both systems eventually moved into the Gulf of Maine during the early morning hours of the 13th.|Precipitation was a wintry mix of heavy wet snow, sleet and rain with the greatest snowfall totals occurring in the higher elevations. Snowfall was generally 5 to 7 inches in the slightly higher elevations of the Adirondacks with lesser amounts in the lower valleys. Some specific snowfall totals include; 7 inches in Dannemora (Clinton county) and Minerva (Essex county) with 6 inches in Saranac (Clinton county), Moriah and Newcomb (Essex county).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A major spring storm brought snowfall totals of 7 to 11 inches across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure organized over the southeastern United States during the evening of Saturday April 14th, and tracked northeast along the East Coast Sunday the 15th, to Long Island on Monday the 16th. The low pressure system grew into a major late season winter storm by the time it reached the New Jersey coast Sunday evening the 15th. The central pressure of this storm dropped to 963 mb just south of Long Island on the 16th. The storm stalled in the vicinity of Long Island and the southern New England coast from the 16th until Tuesday the 17th when it finally drifted to well off the east coast.  A mix of light rain and snow overspread central New York during the early morning hours of Sunday April 15th. The precipitation was a mixture of mainly light rain and snow across central New York Sunday morning which transitioned to all rain Sunday afternoon. The precipitation changed back to all snow Sunday night north and west of the Catskills in central New York. The rain turned to all snow in the Catskills later in the morning on Monday the 16th. The snow became heavy at times and continued across central New York until tapering off to lighter snow showers and flurries by the early morning hours on Tuesday the 17th. Total storm accumulations ranged from 2 to 4 inches in much of southern and western Steuben County and in the lower terrain of Sullivan County, to 4 to 8 inches in the valleys along the southern tier, to between 1 and 2 feet across much of the Finger Lakes region, the higher terrain of central New York, the Catskills and the Tug Hill Plateau. The snow was heavy and wet bringing down many trees and power lines causing scattered power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A major spring storm brought snowfall totals of 6 to 14 inches across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure organized over the southeastern United States during the evening of Saturday April 14th, and tracked northeast along the East Coast Sunday the 15th, to Long Island on Monday the 16th. The snow became heavy at times and continued across central New York until tapering off to lighter snow showers and flurries by the early morning hours on Tuesday the 17th. Total storm accumulations ranged from 2 to 4 inches in much of southern and western Steuben County and in the lower terrain of Sullivan County, to 4 to 8 inches in the valleys along the southern tier, to between 1 and 2 feet across much of the Finger Lakes region, the higher terrain of central New York, the Catskills and the Tug Hill Plateau. The snow was heavy and wet bringing down many trees and power lines causing scattered power outages.

Low pressure developed over the lower Mississippi Valley on Saturday April 14th, and then moved northeast while intensifying, reaching the southern Appalachians by Sunday morning, April 15th, and then just south of western Long Island by Monday morning, April 16th.  This low became very intense, with a central barometric pressure falling below 970 millibars upon reaching just south of Long Island Monday morning.  The low then headed off the New England coast by Tuesday morning.|As a result of this intense storm, heavy wet snow and sleet fell across much of the southern Adirondacks, Mohawk Valley, the Lake George and Saratoga Springs region, extending into the eastern Catskills. The snow began Sunday morning, and continued through Sunday night. The heaviest snowfall occurred at higher elevations, especially above 1500 feet.|Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 16 inches, with the greatest amounts across the higher elevations. Some of the highest amounts included 16 inches at Indian Lake, 13.8 inches at Middle Grove, 13.5 inches at Caroga Lake, and 13 inches Rensselaerville.|The heavy wet snowfall, combined with gusty winds, led to numerous downed tree limbs and power lines, which resulted in widespread power outages, particularly across Hamilton county.|The snow eventually mixed with, and changed to rain by Monday morning.

The snow became heavy at times and continued across central New York until tapering off to lighter snow showers and flurries by the early morning hours on Tuesday the 17th. Total storm accumulations ranged from 2 to 4 inches in much of southern and western Steuben County and in the lower terrain of Sullivan County, to 4 to 8 inches in the valleys along the southern tier, to between 1 and 2 feet across much of the Finger Lakes region, the higher terrain of central New York, the Catskills and the Tug Hill Plateau. The snow was heavy and wet bringing down many trees and power lines causing scattered power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A major spring storm brought about 6 to 17 inches of snow to the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure organized over the southeastern United States during the evening of Saturday April 14th, and tracked northeast along the East Coast Sunday the 15th, to Long Island on Monday the 16th. The central pressure of this storm dropped to 963 mb just south of Long Island on the 16th. The storm stalled in the vicinity of Long Island and the southern New England coast from the 16th until Tuesday the 17th when it finally drifted to well off the east coast. Low pressure developed over the lower Mississippi Valley on Saturday April 14th, and then moved northeast while intensifying, reaching the southern Appalachians by Sunday morning, April 15th, and then just south of western Long Island by Monday morning, April 16th.  This low became very intense, with a central barometric pressure falling below 970 millibars upon reaching just south of Long Island Monday morning.  The low then headed off the New England coast by Tuesday morning.|As a result of this intense storm, heavy wet snow and sleet fell across much of the southern Adirondacks, Mohawk Valley, the Lake George and Saratoga Springs region, extending into the eastern Catskills. The snow began Sunday morning, and continued through Sunday night. The heaviest snowfall occurred at higher elevations, especially above 1500 feet.|Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 16 inches, with the greatest amounts across the higher elevations. Some of the highest amounts included 16 inches at Indian Lake, 13.8 inches at Middle Grove, 13.5 inches at Caroga Lake, and 13 inches Rensselaerville.|The heavy wet snowfall, combined with gusty winds, led to numerous downed tree limbs and power lines, which resulted in widespread power outages, particularly across Hamilton county.|The snow eventually mixed with, and changed to rain by Monday morning.

A storm system initiated across the southern Rockies on the 12th and moved across the southern Plains on the 13th into the Gulf coast states on the 14th. On the 14th, this storm intensified rapidly across the southeast United States and continued that trend, as it moved along the Eastern seaboard on the 15th to the western tip of Long Island, NY on the morning of the 16th. Thereafter, this powerful Nor���easter drifted east of New England.|In northern New York, a mixture of snow and rain overspread the area during the late morning of the 15th. Eventually, the precipitation changed to snow as the intensity of the precipitation increased during the afternoon and continued into the early morning hours of the 16th, before gradually tapering off during the late morning and early afternoon hours of the 16th.|The heaviest precipitation and largest snowfall totals were across the Adirondacks of Clinton and Essex counties, yet significant wet snowfall occurred within the St. Lawrence River valley due to colder air across the region. Snowfall totals were generally 6 to 9 inches in the valleys with locally more than a foot in the higher elevations of the eastern Adirondacks. This was a heavy, wet snow that caused numerous power outages, as well as extremely slick and treacherous roads that resulted in numerous vehicle accidents and forced road closures. There were two separate single-car crashes on Interstate 87 during the late afternoon and evening of the 15th, which resulted in a total of two fatalities and 6 injuries requiring hospitalization. Local State of Emergencies were declared for Essex and Clinton counties. |Some specific snowfall totals included: 6 inches in Canton (St. Lawrence county) and Whippleville (Franklin county)���7 inches in Plattsburgh (Clinton county), Bloomingdale (Essex county) and Edwards (St. Lawrence county)��� 8 inches in Peru (Clinton county), Duane (Franklin county) and Norfolk (St. Lawrence county)���10 inches in Malone (Franklin county)���12 inches in Ellenburg Depot (Clinton county) and Jay (Essex county) with 16 inches at Crown Point (Essex county).

A storm system initiated across the southern Rockies on the 12th and moved across the southern Plains on the 13th into the Gulf coast states on the 14th. On the 14th, this storm intensified rapidly across the southeast United States and continued that trend, as it moved along the Eastern seaboard on the 15th to the western tip of Long Island, NY on the morning of the 16th. Thereafter, this powerful Nor���easter drifted east of New England.|In northern New York, a mixture of snow and rain overspread the area during the late morning of the 15th. Eventually, the precipitation changed to snow as the intensity of the precipitation increased during the afternoon and continued into the early morning hours of the 16th, before gradually tapering off during the late morning and early afternoon hours of the 16th.|The heaviest precipitation and largest snowfall totals were across the Adirondacks of Clinton and Essex counties, yet significant wet snowfall occurred within the St. Lawrence River valley due to colder air across the region. Snowfall totals were generally 6 to 9 inches in the valleys with locally more than a foot in the higher elevations of the eastern Adirondacks. This was a heavy, wet snow that caused numerous power outages, as well as extremely slick and treacherous roads that resulted in numerous vehicle accidents and forced road closures. There were two separate single-car crashes on Interstate 87 during the late afternoon and evening of the 15th, which resulted in a total of two fatalities and 6 injuries requiring hospitalization. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half inch of ice was measured in New Hartford.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracked across upstate New York on Sunday, December 2nd, while a secondary storm developed and gained strength along the New England coast. These two systems brought a mix of precipitation to upstate New York. Many areas of upstate New York changed over to rain, but in Oneida County, the precipitation remained freezing rain, with around one-half inch of ice reported.

A surface low moved across northern New York during the morning of December 3rd. Snow overspread the region during the afternoon of December 2nd and changed to a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain during the early morning hours of the 3rd before gradually ending by midday as scattered snow showers. ||Snowfall amounts were 6 to 12 inches across the northern St. Lawrence River Valley and northern slopes of the northern Adirondacks of northern New York, where there was less of a mixture of sleet and freezing rain. Meanwhile, 3 to 6 inches of snow along with ice accumulations up to 1/4 of an inch occurred across the southern St. Lawrence River Valley and the Adirondacks of southeast St. Lawrence and southern Franklin counties. Some of the higher snowfall totals included; 12 inches in Potsdam (St. Lawrence county) and Bombay (Franklin county), 10 inches in Norfolk and Canton (St. Lawrence county) and 8 inches in Malone (Franklin county).||This was the first widespread winter storm of the 2007-08 season, which resulted in numerous vehicle accidents as well as cancellations of schools, businesses and civic organizations.

A surface low moved across northern New York during the morning of December 3rd. Snow overspread the eastern Adirondacks and the Champlain Valley of New York during the afternoon of December 2nd and changed to a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain during the early morning hours of the 3rd before tapering off to scattered snow and rain showers by midday. However, some additional light accumulating snow redeveloped during the late afternoon and continued into the late evening hours as a secondary coastal low moved from southeast Massachusetts into the Gulf of Maine during the afternoon and evening. ||Snowfall amounts were 3 to 7 inches along with ice accumulations up to 1/4 of an inch. This was the first widespread winter storm of the 2007-08 season, which resulted in numerous vehicle accidents as well as cancellations of schools, businesses and civic organizations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A significant mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain developed Sunday evening, and ended Monday morning.||Snowfall accumulations ranged from 1 to 3 inches, with ice accretions of between one half of an inch, and three quarters of an inch reported. Much of the ice accumulated on roadways, creating treacherous travel conditions Sunday night and Monday morning.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the western Great Lakes on Sunday, December 2nd, moved rapidly east into central New York State by Monday morning on December 3rd, before moving east northeast and intensifying in the Canadian maritimes by Tuesday December 4th.||As a warm front associated with this storm system approached from the southwest, a swath of snow, sleet and freezing rain developed across much of east central New York Sunday afternoon, and persisted into early Monday morning before tapering off as scattered rain and snow showers.||A significant accumulation of snow and ice occurred across portions of the upper Hudson Valley, the Mohawk Valley and the southern Adirondacks from this storm system. In these areas, several inches of snow and sleet fell, in addition to between one half of an inch, and three quarters of an inch of ice accretion. Further south, snow and sleet accumulations generally were between 1 and 2 inches, in addition to a few tenths of an inch of ice accretion.||This wintry mix led to hazardous travel conditions for the Monday morning commute.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A significant mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain developed Sunday evening, and ended Monday morning.||Snowfall accumulations ranged from 1 to 3 inches, with ice accretions of between one half of an inch, and three quarters of an inch reported. Much of the ice accumulated on roadways, creating treacherous travel conditions Sunday night and Monday morning.

In these areas, several inches of snow and sleet fell, in addition to between one half of an inch, and three quarters of an inch of ice accretion. Further south, snow and sleet accumulations generally were between 1 and 2 inches, in addition to a few tenths of an inch of ice accretion.||This wintry mix led to hazardous travel conditions for the Monday morning commute.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of precipitation across the county was followed by heavy wrap-around snow. Snowfall totals ranged from 8 to 18 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Southern Plains to the Ohio Valley before tracking across Southern Pennsylvania to Southern New England. Snow overspread much of the area on the evening of the 15th, before mixing with and changing over to sleet and freezing rain. The highest snowfall totals occurred across the Northern Finger Lakes, Western Mohawk Valley and Tug Hill Plateau, where persistent wrap around snow occurred as the storm redeveloped into a major winter storm on the East Coast. In these areas, snowfall amounts ranged between 10 and 18 inches.

A powerful primary upper level and surface low across the Ohio River Valley on the morning of December 16th spawned a secondary coastal low in the Delmarva Peninsula. Both systems merged across southern New England during the afternoon of the 16th and then moved into the Gulf of Maine at night.||Snow overspread northern New York just after midnight on the 16th and briefly mixed with sleet during the late morning and early afternoon hours before steadier and heavier snow returned during the late afternoon hours and continued until just after midnight on the 17th. Brisk northwest winds of 10 to 20 mph accompanied the steadier snowfall in the late afternoon and evening hours and that resulted in considerable blowing and drifting of the snow with greatly reduced visibilities.||Storm total snowfall accumulations across northern New York was 9 to 15 inches with some locally higher amounts. Some of the higher snowfall totals included; 17 inches in Ellenburg Depot (Clinton county), 16 inches in Potsdam (St. Lawrence county) and 14 inches in Whippleville (Franklin county).

A powerful primary upper level and surface low across the Ohio River Valley on the morning of December 16th spawned a secondary coastal low in the Delmarva Peninsula. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed during the early morning hours of Sunday, December 16th, and ended early Monday morning. Sleet mixed in with the snow at times, particularly during Sunday afternoon and evening.||Total snowfall amounts generally ranged from 6 to 9 inches, with 9 inches reported at Jefferson, and 5.5 inches reported in Schoharie. ||The heavy snow and sleet led to numerous school and business closings Monday morning. In addition, the snow and sleet created hazardous driving conditions for the Monday morning commute.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system traveled from the lower Mississippi Valley into the lower Ohio Valley on Saturday, December 15th. This low then redeveloped just off the Delmarva peninsula by Sunday morning, December 16th, and intensified rapidly, becoming the primary low center. This low then tracked into the Canadian maritimes by Monday morning.||This storm system brought a significant mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region, beginning early Sunday morning, and persisting into Sunday night.||Across the southern and western Adirondacks and western Mohawk Valley region, as well as the Capital Region, the Lake George and Saratoga region, and the Helderbergs, snow and sleet accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches. Further south, snow and sleet amounts of 2 to 6 inches fell across the mid Hudson Valley and southeast Catskills, in addition to several tenths of an inch of ice accretion from freezing rain.||The heavy snow and sleet accumulations led to the closings of numerous schools and businesses Monday morning, and also created treacherous driving conditions from Sunday into Monday morning.||In addition, across the central Taconics, the combination of several tenths of an inch of ice accretion and gusty winds led to downed trees and powerlines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow and sleet developed during the early morning hours of Sunday, December 16th, before changing to freezing rain and sleet by mid morning. The sleet and freezing rain then persisted through Sunday evening, before changing back to snow Sunday night. The snow then tapered off by early Monday morning.||Snow and sleet accumulations of 2 to 5 inches fell from this storm, in addition to several tenths of an inch of ice accretion. The ice accretion, combined with gusty winds, led to numerous downed trees and wires across the County, particularly in Copake, Hillsdale, Austerlitz, Canaan, and Ancram.||The significant wintry mix of precipitation led to numerous school and business closings on Monday morning, and also created treacherous travel conditions for the Monday morning commute.

Further south, snow and sleet amounts of 2 to 6 inches fell across the mid Hudson Valley and southeast Catskills, in addition to several tenths of an inch of ice accretion from freezing rain.||The heavy snow and sleet accumulations led to the closings of numerous schools and businesses Monday morning, and also created treacherous driving conditions from Sunday into Monday morning.||In addition, across the central Taconics, the combination of several tenths of an inch of ice accretion and gusty winds led to downed trees and powerlines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow developed during the early morning hours of Sunday, December 16th, and ended early Monday morning. Sleet mixed in with the snow at times, particularly during Sunday afternoon and evening.||Total snowfall amounts generally ranged from 6 to 9 inches, with 8.5 inches reported at Schenectady, and 7.6 reported in Niskayuna. ||The heavy snow and sleet led to numerous school and business closings Monday morning. In addition, the snow and sleet created hazardous driving conditions for the Monday morning commute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked northeast from the Carolina coast to east of Cape Cod from the afternoon of the 29th through the morning of the 30th. Snow spread into upstate New York during the evening on Sunday and continued overnight before tapering off Monday morning. Snowfall amounts ranged generally between 5 and 10 inches.

Low pressure across the Great Lakes on the morning of January 1st moved across New York and New England during the late afternoon and evening hours. Meanwhile, a secondary area of low pressure developed across southern New England during the afternoon of the 1st and moved into the Gulf of Maine during the night. Snow overspread northern New York around noon on the 1st and continued into the early morning hours of the 2nd.||Snowfall amounts with this storm were 6 to 10 inches across much of the Adirondacks and St. Lawrence River Valley. Some specific snowfall amounts included; 10 inches in Edwards and Ogdensburg (St. Lawrence county), 9 inches in Whippleville and Malone (Franklin county) with 6 inches in Ellenburg Depot (Clinton county) and Gouverneur (St. Lawrence county).

Low pressure lifted north from the Tennessee valley and spread initially snow, then a mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet, across parts of the region. Snowfalls ranged from five to eleven inches followed by a couple inches of sleet or a coating of ice.

An arctic high pressure system was located across New England and New York on January 31st into the morning hours of February 1st. Meanwhile, a powerful storm system moved from the southern Plains on the morning of January 31st into the Ohio River Valley by the morning of February 1st and then across New England during the night of February 1st. This storm system transported a great deal of moisture and milder air above a surface that had a cold, dry airmass established across the region.||This resulted in a significant wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain across portions of northern New York. Snow began by mid-morning on February 1st across northern New York and changed to sleet and freezing rain during the afternoon that continued during the night, before changing back to snow showers prior to ending during the early morning hours of the 2nd.||Combined snow and sleet accumulations across northern New York was 3 to 6 inches along with accumulating ice between one quarter to under one half an inch. This wintry mix accounted for hazardous road conditions, numerous vehicle accidents and multiple school, civic and government closings on February 1st.

A low pressure system tracked northeast from the Ohio Valley into northern New England on Friday, February 1st, producing a significant mix of mainly sleet and freezing rain across portions of east central New York and adjacent western New England.||Precipitation began as a mix of snow and sleet Friday morning, before changing to sleet and freezing rain by early Friday afternoon. The precipitation then became mainly freezing rain, before changing to plain rain Friday evening.||Snow and sleet accumulations of 3 to 6 inches fell across portions of the southern Adirondacks, with amounts of 1 to 3 inches further south into the Lake George and Saratoga region, as well as across portions of the eastern Catskills, Schoharie Valley and Helderbergs.||In addition, ice accretion from freezing rain of one quarter, to one third of an inch fell across much of the Adirondacks, Mohawk Valley and the Lake George and Saratoga regions. This wintry mix led to hazardous travel conditions for the Friday evening commute, with numerous accidents reported. In addition, scattered power outages were reported due to downed limbs from ice accretion.

The precipitation then became mainly freezing rain, before changing to plain rain Friday evening.||Snow and sleet accumulations of 3 to 6 inches fell across portions of the southern Adirondacks, with amounts of 1 to 3 inches further south into the Lake George and Saratoga region, as well as across portions of the eastern Catskills, Schoharie Valley and Helderbergs.||In addition, ice accretion from freezing rain of one quarter, to one third of an inch fell across much of the Adirondacks, Mohawk Valley and the Lake George and Saratoga regions. This wintry mix led to hazardous travel conditions for the Friday evening commute, with numerous accidents reported. In addition, scattered power outages were reported due to downed limbs from ice accretion.

On February 6th, two areas of low pressure traveled along a boundary, previously left by a storm on February 5th. The first low traveled across New York and New England during the morning of February 6th and the next system moved along the southern New England coast during the night of the 6th into the morning hours of the 7th.||Snow overspread northern New York during the early morning hours of the 6th and was briefly heavy during the morning commute before it tapered off to scattered snow showers by late morning. Meanwhile, another area of low pressure moved toward the region during the evening with another period of steady snow that continued into the early morning hours of the 7th.||Storm total snowfall across the Adirondacks and Champlain Valley of New York was 8 to 14 inches, which included 14 inches in Peru (Clinton county), 12 inches in Schuyler Falls (Clinton county), Newcomb (Essex county), Saranac Lake and Tupper Lake (Franklin county). Snowfall amounts and intensity of snowfall during the morning commute of the 6th caused numerous vehicle accidents and school cancellations.

A low pressure system tracked east northeast from the lower Ohio Valley on Wednesday morning, February 6th, to just south of Cape Cod by Thursday morning on February 7th. This storm system spread a swath of moderate to locally heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain across portions of east central New York and adjacent western New England from Wednesday morning into Thursday morning.||Snow and sleet amounts ranged from 6 to 12 inches across portions of the southern and western Adirondacks, with generally under 3 inches elsewhere. However, ice accretion from freezing rain ranged between one quarter, to just under one half of an inch, with the greatest amounts across the higher elevations of the central and southern Taconics, as well as across the Lake George and Saratoga region. The ice accretion led to scattered power outages as a result of downed tree limbs on power lines.||The precipitation changed to snow before ending across the region Thursday morning.||This wintry mix created hazardous travel conditions, which led to numerous traffic accidents across the region from late Wednesday morning into early Thursday morning, with most occurring during the Wednesday evening commute.

A complex low pressure system over the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys Tuesday afternoon, February 12, lifted northeast into the lower Great Lakes region early Wednesday morning, February 13. As the occluded front approached the east coast Wednesday afternoon, a secondary low developed along the triple point over southern New Jersey, then tracked northeast and off the southern New England coast in the evening. Light to moderate snow broke out across the region Tuesday afternoon. As the cold air eroded with the primary low tracking to the west, the precipitation transitioned to freezing rain during the early morning hours Wednesday. Prior to the changeover, 3 to 6 inches of snow fell, followed by 1/4 to 1/2 inch of ice. Temperatures rose above freezing in the mid to late morning hours with a transition to plain rain.

A complex low pressure system over the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys Tuesday afternoon, February 12, lifted northeast into the lower Great Lakes region early Wednesday morning, February 13. Light to moderate snow broke out across the region Tuesday afternoon. As the cold air eroded with the primary low tracking to the west, the precipitation transitioned to freezing rain during the early morning hours Wednesday. Prior to the changeover, 3 to 6 inches of snow fell, followed by 1/4 to 1/2 inch of ice. Temperatures rose above freezing in the mid to late morning hours with a transition to plain rain.

A low pressure system tracked from the southern Appalachians into western New York State Tuesday February 12th into Wednesday February 13th, while a secondary low pressure system developed south of Long Island by Wednesday afternoon, before tracking northeast off the northern New England coast by Wednesday evening.||This complex storm system brought a significant wintry mix to much of east central New York and adjacent western New England, beginning Tuesday evening, and ending Wednesday evening.||Snow and sleet accumulations generally ranged from 5 to 10 inches across the southern Adirondacks, with 3 to 6 inches occurring further south into the Mohawk Valley, Lake George and Saratoga region, extending south into the Capital Region, Schoharie Valley, and higher elevations of the eastern Catskills.||In addition, ice accretion from freezing rain ranged from one quarter to one half of an inch, with the greatest amounts within the Lake George and Saratoga region, particularly near Glens Falls, as well as across higher elevations of the central and southern Taconics. This ice accretion led to downed tree limbs, trees and power lines across the hardest hit regions, as well as scattered power outages.||This significant wintry mix led to numerous school closings and treacherous travel conditions Wednesday morning. Dozens of accidents were reported during the Wednesday morning commute due to ice covered roadways, with several cars reportedly veering off the Adirondack Northway in Wilton, Lake George and Chester. In addition, many businesses either were closed, or had delayed openings Wednesday morning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 4 to 8 inches of snow to the region before changing over to a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked northeast from the Tennessee Valley to Central New York before moving off the New England coast during the afternoon on the 13th. Snow overspread much of Central New York, with a few inches falling before changing over to a mix of precipitation. Between 4 and 8 inches of snow fell across Oneida County before the change over to  a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 4 to 8 inches of snow to the region before changing over to a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked northeast from the Tennessee Valley to Central New York before moving off the New England coast during the afternoon on the 13th. Snow overspread much of Central New York, with a few inches falling before changing over to a mix of precipitation. Between 4 and 8 inches of snow fell across Oneida County before the change over to  a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain.

Low pressure across the southern Mississippi River Valley on the morning of February 12th moved across the Ohio River Valley during the 12th and into New York and New England on the 13th. Snow overspread St. Lawrence county New York during the late evening hours of the 12th and continued until early afternoon on the 13th. Snow mixed with sleet at times during the course of the storm with combined snow and sleet accumulations of 5 to 10 inches across St. Lawrence county.

Snow overspread St. Lawrence county New York during the late evening hours of the 12th and continued until early afternoon on the 13th. Snow mixed with sleet at times during the course of the storm with combined snow and sleet accumulations of 5 to 10 inches across St. Lawrence county.

Snow mixed with sleet at times during the course of the storm with combined snow and sleet accumulations of 5 to 10 inches across St. Lawrence county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 9 to 11 inches of snow to the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moved across the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic region, spreading snow and mixed precipitation across the Southern Catskills. Around 10 inches of snow fell before changing over to mixed precipitation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county averaged around 7 inches. Numerous accidents occurred along Interstate 86, and on secondary roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Central Plains and intensified as it moved across Southern Pennsylvania and then to the New England coast. The storm brought heavy snow accumulations to much of Central New York. Snowfall amounts ranged generally between 5 and 10 inches with locally over 1 foot in northern Oneida County.

Low pressure across the Mississippi River Valley during the afternoon of February 25th moved through the Ohio River Valley on the 26th and across southern New England on the night of the 26th into the Gulf of Maine by the morning of February 27th. Snow overspread northern New York during the morning of the 26th and continued through the morning hours of the 27th before tapering to scattered snow showers by midday. ||Snowfall accumulations across northern New York were 6 to 12 inches along with some blowing and drifting snow due to brisk northwest winds of 15 to 25 mph with higher gusts. Some specific snowfall totals included; 11 inches in Ellenburg Depot (Clinton county), 9 inches in Tupper Lake (Franklin county) with 8 inches in Plattsburgh (Clinton county) and Newcomb (Essex county).

Low pressure across the Mississippi River Valley during the afternoon of February 25th moved through the Ohio River Valley on the 26th and across southern New England on the night of the 26th into the Gulf of Maine by the morning of February 27th. Low pressure developed over the lower Mississippi valley and lifted to the Ohio valley. The storm brought a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region. A general snow of four to six inches blanketed the entire region and was followed by several inches of sleet and up to a half inch of glaze from freezing rain.  Schools were closed in many parts of the region. Some County officials declared States of Emergency, while others recommended no unnecessary travel. Utility companies reported scattered power outages affected tens of thousands of customers across the region.

A powerful winter storm moved from the lower Mississippi River Valley on the morning of March 4th, into the Ohio River Valley during the night and across New England on the 5th. ||Snow and sleet overspread northern New York during the night of March 4th and accumulated several inches prior to changing to freezing rain during the early morning hours of the 5th. Freezing rain accumulated around an half inch across northern New York during the morning of March 5th, prior to it ended before noon.||School cancellations, scattered power outages and numerous vehicle accidents resulted from the very hazardous conditions.

One of the worst storms of the 2007-2008 winter season occurred on from the 7th through the 9th. This was an extended two part event but totals of one to two feet were common, with some isolated higher amounts. The storm occurred over a weekend so impact to daily activities (school and businesses) was minimal. Numerous automobile accidents were blamed on the slippery conditions and poor visibilities in falling and blowing snow. The 21.6 inch total measured at the Buffalo Airport was the greatest general (non-lake effect) snowfall in Buffalo in 24 years. Other snowfall reports included: 30 inches at Ellicottville; 26 inches at Lockport and Perrysburg; 24 inches at Depew; 23 inches at Getzville; 22 inches at North Tonawanda and Hamlin; 21 inches at Hamburg, Amherst and Niagara Falls; 18 inches at Brockport, Colden, Sinclairville, and Warsaw; 17 inches as Copenhagen, Forestville and South Dayton; 16 inches at Darien and Scottsburg; 15 inches at Colden, Gaines, Pulaski and Basom; 14 inches at Middleport, Lacona, and Webster; 13 inches as Greece, Hannibal and Kennedy; and 12 inches at Cato, Bennetts Bridge and Marion.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals across the county ranged from 6 to 10 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading a variety of precipitation across central New York and northeast Pennsylvania from later Friday through Sunday morning. A major ice storm occurred across much of the Finger Lakes Region of New York, with mainly snow north of here, and heavy rain to the south. Ice accumulations ranged from one half to three quarters of an inch bringing down many trees and power lines in the Finger Lakes region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals across the county ranged from 3 inches in Van Buren to 12.8 inches in Clay.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading a variety of precipitation across central New York and northeast Pennsylvania from later Friday through Sunday morning. A major ice storm occurred across much of the Finger Lakes Region of New York, with mainly snow north of here, and heavy rain to the south. Ice accumulations ranged from one half to three quarters of an inch bringing down many trees and power lines in the Finger Lakes region.

Arctic high pressure was located across the Great Lakes on March 7th and retreated across Ontario province Canada on March 8th. Meanwhile, a deep upper atmospheric trough lifted a mild and very moist surface low from the Gulf of Mexico on the 7th across New England on the 8th. The clash between air masses and abundant moisture accounted for a heavy precipitation event across northern New York.||The close proximity to the deeper, arctic air across Ontario province accounted for a snow mixed with sleet at the onset on the night of the 7th that changed to mainly snow on the 8th across the St. Lawrence River Valley. Meanwhile, rain overspread the Champlain Valley during the evening of March 7th with scattered areas of freezing rain and sleet along the Canadian border. On March 8th, colder air filtered into the Champlain Valley near the surface, which changed precipitation to a prolonged period of heavy freezing rain and sleet that ended during the evening.||Sleet and freezing rain caused havoc across the Champlain Valley of New York with an inch or more of sleet as well as an half inch or more of ice accumulation from freezing rain. While, heavy snow and sleet accumulation in the Adirondacks and St. Lawrence River Valley caused equal amounts of problems.||Numerous vehicle accidents, downed tree limbs, power lines and power outages impacted portions of northern New York.

Arctic high pressure was located across the Great Lakes on March 7th and retreated across Ontario province Canada on March 8th. Meanwhile, a deep upper atmospheric trough lifted a mild and very moist surface low from the Gulf of Mexico on the 7th across New England on the 8th. The clash between air masses and abundant moisture accounted for a heavy precipitation event across northern New York.||The close proximity to the deeper, arctic air across Ontario province accounted for a snow mixed with sleet at the onset on the night of the 7th that changed to mainly snow on the 8th across the St. Lawrence River Valley. A strengthening low pressure system tracked northeast from the Ohio Valley on Tuesday March 18th, to a position along the Maine coast by Thursday morning on March 20th. The low then continued to intensify upon reaching the Canadian Maritimes by Friday morning on March 21st.||This storm system initially brought a swath of light to moderate snowfall across the southern Adirondacks from Tuesday into early Wednesday, with accumulations of 1 to 3 inches.||As a cold northwest flow developed in the wake of this storm system, some lake enhanced snowbands developed Thursday night into Friday morning, which produced additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 8 inches, mainly across higher, west facing slopes in northern Herkimer county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulations across the northern part of the county ranged from 3 to 10 inches, with the higher amounts across higher elevations. Point Pock measured 10.0 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Monday afternoon and evening, October 28th, 2008, a frontal system stalled across the eastern seaboard, with an area of light rain across eastern New York State. A wave of low pressure began to organize along this front just off the New Jersey coast early Tuesday morning. This low pressure system rapidly intensified into a major early season winter storm as it crawled up the Hudson River Valley Tuesday and Tuesday evening. As a result, a widespread area of heavy precipitation spread across most of central and eastern New York by Tuesday morning.  Northerly winds developed, which drew down colder air and resulted in a changeover to snow late Monday night over the highest elevations, with snow levels dropping to around 1500 feet in upstate New York and to around 1000 feet in the Catskills by late Tuesday morning.  ||Locations above 1500 feet in the Catskills received 1 to 2 feet of heavy wet snow. Roxbury, NY at 2500 feet received 25.6 inches of snow. Across elevations between 1000 and 1500 feet in the Catskills, snowfall ranged from 2 to 6 inches. In central New York, above 1500 feet, snowfall ranged from 2 to 8 inches, with up to a foot of snow in Oneida and Madison counties. ||Very strong northwest winds developed across central New York behind this storm. Winds gusts ranged from 40 to 50 mph in most places. In areas where there was heavy wet snow, major damage was done to trees and power lines leading to widespread power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulations were widely variable across the county, with most areas receiving from 5 to 10 inches. The highest amount was measured in Roxbury, with 25.6 inches.

A vigorous and largely amplified upper atmospheric trough across the Great Lakes and east coast of the United States developed a strong, cold autumnal storm along a cold frontal boundary late on October 27th into the early hours of October 28th. This storm strengthened rapidly as it traveled north along a cold front across central New England on the 28th.||Sub-freezing air across northern New York, especially away from Lake Champlain accounted for a significant accumulation of heavy, wet snow across the Adirondacks and St. Lawrence River Valley. Snowfall accumulations of more than a foot occurred across much of the Adirondacks with 6 to 12 inches within the St. Lawrence River Valley.||Some specific snowfall accumulations included; 18 inches in Wanakena (St. Lawrence county), 16 inches in Tupper Lake (Franklin county), 15 inches in Lake Placid (Essex county) and 14 inches in Saranac Lake (Franklin county).||Significant accumulations of heavy wet snowfall accounted for scattered tree damage and power outages as well as numerous vehicle accidents across the region.

An intense east coast storm lifted north across New England on Tuesday the 28th and brought an early season snowstorm to the Eastern Lake Ontario Region. The precipitation began as rain, but gradually changed over to snow during the afternoon and early evening. The snow was very heavy and wet and there were numerous reports of tree damage and broken limbs. Scattered power outages were reported. Specific snowfall reports included:  21��� at Redfield; 19��� at Hooker; 18��� at Harrisville; 16��� at Adams; 14��� at Carthage; and 8��� at Brownville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the area ranged from 4 to 9 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mixture of precipitation spread east as a low pressure system and cold front moved east from the plains to the northeastern United States. Most valley locations received a mix of rain and snow, while wet snow fell at the higher elevations. The heaviest snow fell across northern Oneida County where 4 to 9 inches accumulated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation brought 0.25 to 0.50 inch of ice accumulation to parts of the county, especially on the hilltops. The mixed precipitation then changed over to all snow, with accumulations of 4 to 8 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked from the Gulf of Mexico, the evening of the 10th, through the Carolinas on the 11th, to New England on the 12th. |This storm brought a variety of wintry precipitation to central New York from the morning of the 11th to the morning of the 12th. A band of heavy snow developed across central New York from the Finger Lakes area to Onondaga and Madison counties where between 5 and 10 inches of snow fell. Further east, significant icing occurred across a large part of Chenango, Delaware and Otsego Counties, which received a half inch or more of ice. The rest of central New York received around a quarter inch of ice and from 2 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county ranged from 5 to 9 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked from the Gulf of Mexico, the evening of the 10th, through the Carolinas on the 11th, to New England on the 12th. |This storm brought a variety of wintry precipitation to central New York from the morning of the 11th to the morning of the 12th. A band of heavy snow developed across central New York from the Finger Lakes area to Onondaga and Madison counties where between 5 and 10 inches of snow fell. Further east, significant icing occurred across a large part of Chenango, Delaware and Otsego Counties, which received a half inch or more of ice. The rest of central New York received around a quarter inch of ice and from 2 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county averaged around 7 inches.

The rest of central New York received around a quarter inch of ice and from 2 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant icing occurred at the higher elevations of the county, especially at 2000 feet and above. Ice amounts averaged around 0.50 inch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 7 to 10 inches across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked from the Gulf of Mexico, the evening of the 10th, through the Carolinas on the 11th, to New England on the 12th. |This storm brought a variety of wintry precipitation to central New York from the morning of the 11th to the morning of the 12th. A band of heavy snow developed across central New York from the Finger Lakes area to Onondaga and Madison counties where between 5 and 10 inches of snow fell. Further east, significant icing occurred across a large part of Chenango, Delaware and Otsego Counties, which received a half inch or more of ice. The rest of central New York received around a quarter inch of ice and from 2 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 9 inches across the county.

Further east, significant icing occurred across a large part of Chenango, Delaware and Otsego Counties, which received a half inch or more of ice. The rest of central New York received around a quarter inch of ice and from 2 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation brought significant accumulations of ice to parts of the county, especially to areas above 2000 ft. elevation, where 0.50 inch to as much as 1.00 inch of ice accumulated. After the precipitation changed over to snow, snowfall amounts ranged from about 4 to 7 inches.
